title: Would anyone actually be mad if an "OP" mobility killer came out?
body:
{{champion:17}}  Shrooms don't cut it anymore, to many dashes.

An actual champion that thrives off of killing mobile ones might actually briig the less mobile ones back into meta/playability as well.

They picked {{champion:429}}  and {{champion:245}} ? Grab a mobility-killer and punish them.
They pic something more traditional, like {{champion:99}}  and {{champion:15}} ? Maybe Mr/Mrs. Anti-mobility isn't the right pick here.

I'm not saying I know how to implement this (interrupts/disables dashes maybe?) but would people really be OK if that happened?

replies.body:
Bloodseeker vs Kalista

It becomes a question of "how much can Kalista lifesteal" and "whether Bloodseeker can chase fast enough"...

I remember ages ago (like, S1, on the old LoL forums) a rioter used rupture as an example of a skill that they think is poorly designed.

Here I actually found it. [Link](http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=293417). Zileas talked about it in 2010

[Discussing "Burden of Knowledge"]

> "This is a VERY common pattern amongst hardcore novice game designers. This pattern is when you do a complex mechanic that creates gameplay -- ONLY IF the victim understands what is going on. Rupture is a great example -- with Rupture in DOTA, you receive a DOT that triggers if you, the victim, choose to move. However, you have no way of knowing this is happening unless someone tells you or unless you read up on it online... So the initial response is extreme frustration. We believe that giving the victim counter gameplay is VERY fun -- but that we should not place a 'burden of knowledge' on them figuring out what that gameplay might be. That's why we like Dark Binding and Black Shield (both of which have bait and/or 'dodge' counter gameplay that is VERY obvious), but not Rupture, which is not obvious."

Earlier in the post, he said more generally and vaguely that 

>Rupture contains several basic design 'anti-patterns'.

 I would guess that maybe he would also accuse it of being a false choice? You can choose to move or stand still when ruptured, but the consequences of moving are severe enough that you would almost always want to stand still. 

Anyways, I'm not necessarily agreeing or disagreeing with Zileas. I just thought I'd throw this out there. I remember reading this post years ago and thinking it was pretty interesting. I'd never heard a game developer talk, in such depth, about design goals and traps before. Even if you don't always agree with him, it's a cool post.

Yes, but when you first playing, that literally holds true for every single thing. I mean, ignite? wut? How did I just die when the enemy ran away from me.

Sure, it might be frustrating for the first time someone plays against the champ, but it wouldn't be an issue at all.

I'd argue VFX and SFX play a big role in determining reaction goals once someone is targeted with a spell.

For example, if it was visually clear and made a ripping noise when a ruptured target was bleeding it would've made it clear that you should only move when necessary.

Ignite application sounds, ticks and even the vision&griveous wounds signal on top of the target make it clear what is about to happen; giving the target more seconds to think of a reaction.

I basically agree with your argument here, but ignite is a much simpler concept. A player might want to know that it reduces healing, and then hold onto their heals until after it wears off, but other than that it doesn't require any special reaction. It's just a DoT. It's not hard to communicate a simple DoT through VFX and SFX. "Hey, I'm on fire, and my health is going down. I guess someone applied some kind of burning DoT to me."

A rupture-like skill would require a much more specific reaction--you not only have to know that some kind of negative effect has been applied to you, you have to know that, specifically, it damages you if you move. I think it would be hard to communicate the idea "you aren't allowed to move" purely through VFX and SFX. You mention a "ripping noise" and "bleeding"... my first reaction, if I saw this in game without knowing what it did, would be to assume that a simple DoT had been applied to me. There are other "bleeding" DoTs in the game. 

There are not very many complicated status effects in League. In my experience, blind probably confuses new players the most, since it is pretty rare and pretty specific. But throwing a huge text box that says "blind" over the target certainly helps to clarify here. A player might not immediately understand what it means to be blinded, but they can probably figure it out pretty quickly, just from the word. 

I think a rupture-like effect, while potentially cool for players who understand it, would be far and away the most complicated status effect in League, and difficult to communicate properly in-game. Any SFX/VFX could be confused for a normal DoT. I also can't think of any simple word that describes what the effect is doing, in the way that "BLIND" instantly describes what's going on.

Champion dialog like Sion's screaming can make this easier.

Imagine if Blood Seeker said: "Go on, move I dare you!" upon casting Rupture; That would make it clear without using any VFX.
The difference there is that Ignite would have killed you anyway, where with Rupture you killed yourself by moving.

And yet Riot proves times and times again, they are hypocritic.

How can one know to not stand near Ekko's ghost without reading it online? Or that he deals bonus damage when you are low? Or that you will take 800 damage if he hits you 3 times?

That's the most recent example.

This has a lot of potential. Not just to counter the hyper mobility creep, but to also give the new champion their own, unique role to fill. If the champion is explicitly balanced around wrecking mobile champs while leaving immobile ones relatively untouched, that will ensure that the champion will be strong when he's needed but weak if picked indiscriminately.

Personally, I feel that this line of thought should apply to every champion. Give them all their own niche to be effective in.

It sounds nice, but really having champions only countered by specific picks is really, really bad game design.

The problem with your mobility killer is similar to the problem with these hyper-mobile champions - it would hard counter any mobile champions, just like the mobile champions hard-counter immobile champions.

As satisfying as it would be to have a pick that completely destroys Kalista, it wouldn't make for a healthy gaming environment.  Something like Kalista just shouldn't exist in the first place.  Her design is so inherently bad.  No amount of band-aid patching by adding a specific hard-counter to her can change that fact.

Riot has gone on record saying they don't want abilities like that in the game; they don't like abilities that punish you for taking the "right" action because it adds too much burden of knowledge and frustrates people who don't know what's happening. They said this about that exact ability.

and it is not frustrating for someoen to fight LB at 100%, then get deleted while LB returns to the same spot within 5 seconds.

Worse, they don't know how to prevent it from happening, while simply observing and not moving for a few seconds means that Rupture doesn't hurt them.

Shit, I still don't know how to prevent LB from 1 shotting me when ahead and not even moving from her original position within 2 seconds.

and it is not frustrating to be kited by Ahri as a melee, even if you are playing a mobile melee light fighter or assassin like Riven, Yasuo, Zed, Master Yi, etc, because you know there's nothing you can do and you lost in champ select due to the overloaded kit of someone with the waveclear and CC of Xerath, but with more dashes than Zed and Fizz.

If LB is kicking your ass, stay out of her zone and get tanky. CC her. Don't be anywhere near her with less than full health (she cannot 100-0 in lane unless she's already fed). Dodge Ahri's abilities, bait her ult out by scaring her or getting her to engage on you. 

These are all counterplay options, and they're all the "right" thing to do.

>they don't like abilities that punish you for taking the "right" action

If a melee champion jumps on your face, the "right" thing to do is to put distance between you and them. If you're a melee champion and a ranged champion gets away from you, the "right" thing to do is close that distance. Those are *always* the right thing to do in general. Start introducing abilities like what you want, and suddenly doing the right thing can get you killed. Riot doesn't want that. QQ about champions you don't like isn't even relevant.

I think an ability close to Ares from Smite. He can shoot a chain that slows enemies, and prevents the use of any movement abilities. This would mean that immobile champions like Cho'Gath would not be cripples, while counting people like LeBlanc, Ekko, etc. He is a description from smite's wiki of Ares ability:
> Chains extend from Ares' shield, doing damage to all enemies in its path. Hitting a god shackles them to Ares, cripples them, preventing movement abilities, dealing the same damage every second while slowing them and buffing Ares. While shackled, Ares can fire another chain for free within 2s.

Riot is not going to implement hard counters to certain champions. If they decided mobility was out of hand enough to need a counter, they'd nerf mobility. Adding in a hard counter just means when he's picked you can't play mobile champs and when he's banned mobile champs are "still OP."

Hmm, that is true. Besides, we don't want this game to degenerate into who picked the better team comp. It should  always be winnable, as long as you didn't do something really stupid like pick 5 supports.

Exactly. So either Riot doesn't think mobility is as out of hand as the loudest people on the forums do, or they're working on it in a slow way. Probably a mix of the two really. I remember a lot of people said new Sion's Q wouldn't work because of mobility, but I think he does pretty good. And the champ update team is still always working. It's not super fast work, and they're probably generally content to let it take its time, but I'd say their goal is less "take away mobility" and more "make sure every champion has some cool things they can do in most situations."
Well in their defence most immobile champs are still fine. It would be easier to fix those that can't compete, as they are fewer.

Having exemptions would make the system complicated, unless you have a more specific idea?

Hm... I'm no programming expert nor am I a game designer... If only getting downvotes for poor ideas rather than being an ass was a profession... Okay, how about I give this tentative idea that I'm sure is heavily flawed:

What if there was a debuff that prevented either offensive or defensive dashing and MS boosts? Similar to how Janna's passive works, this hypothetical champion could reduce mobility at a certain range (either through a spell or a passive, but I'm guessing the former would be less OP). If we went the offensive route, it would be a more defensive champion but it would have more versatility due to gap closers on melee champions. If it went down the defensive route, it would just prevent escapes from mobile champions that were unprepared and make it easier to appropriate punish.

I'd opt for the defensive mobility route for the sake of melee champions with gap closers. Lee Sin's Q, for instance, would work normally, but he wouldn't be able to ward hop in the opposite direction. 

*But,* say it affected gap closers. While it would give more ranged champions on that champion's team more power as a result, it would likely benefit poke mages the most like Lux. That would be nice.

I've thought about your idea and came to conclude it would make most sense if it was a tether champion ability like {{champion:43}}; except it debuffs the target for the duration rather than the end.

If it were to be an AoE ability, it would take a lot of the champion's power budget and likely funnel that champion into a mage/support role where this ability becomes the champion's main attribute with the constraint being a design aspect based on facing direction similar to {{champion:23}} & {{champion:69}}.

Overall I like it and see it possible, the least that could be done is a generic skillshot damage ability + auto attack/movement encouraging passive + some AoE ult.
